issue.title: http: preserve raw header duplicates in writeHead after setHeader calls

labels.name: http
labels.description: Issues or PRs related to the http subsystem.

labels.name: semver-major
labels.description: PRs that contain breaking changes and should be released in the next major version.

labels.name: needs-ci
labels.description: PRs that need a full CI run.

issue.body:
Fixes #50387

`writeHead` accepts a raw header array (flattened as `[k1, v1, k2, v2, k3, v3, ...]`) which is allows directly specifying raw header data - preserving ordering, duplicates and header key casing. When used by itself this works totally fine.

However, if `setHeader` was called first, it effectively changes the behaviour of subsequent `writeHead` calls, so that even if a raw header array was provided, duplicates are collapsed and lost entirely.

This change preserves the duplicate headers passed to `writeHead`, while still maintaining the 'writeHead overwrites setHeader' behaviour from [the docs](https://nodejs.org/api/http.html#responsewriteheadstatuscode-statusmessage-headers) which say:

> When headers have been set with response.setHeader(), they will be merged with any headers passed to response.writeHead(), **with the headers passed to response.writeHead() given precedence**.

This works by switching from setHeader to appendHeader, which does support duplicates. Unfortunately doing that by itself would break the above constraint, because it would merge all setHeader headers with writeHead headers (instead of overwriting them) so instead we first remove conflicting cases (i.e. all the setHeader headers that would be overwritten) and then we can use appendHeader safely, since there are now no remaining conflicts.

An extra loop here may have a small performance implications and I'm sure that writing server responses is a high-sensitivity area there, but notably this is in the section already marked "Slow-case" directly above. In performance sensitive scenarios, applications shouldn't really mix headers between setHeader and writeHead regardless.

Any suggestions to improve that (or anything else) very welcome!

comment.body:
> this is a breaking change. I think Fastify relies on the previous behavior of this function.

@mcollina are you sure? Can you share more information on that? It sounds surprising to me that Fastify would depend on passing duplicates values to writeHead while expecting them not to be sent because of this bug. Note that this doesn't have any effect if you just use `writeHead` by itself without `setHeader`.

Imo 'breaking' is technically debatable, since the existing behaviour is clearly wrong and disagrees with the docs and behaviour elsewhere, but it's yes sensible to do as a semver major anyway just to reduce the risk of unexpected response changes.

> I agree it will probably affect performance, but as Robert said it's a very weird scenario. 

It will be possible to improve performance here I'd expect, reimplementing more of the header update logic inline, rather than calling into both remove/appendHeader (which will mildly duplicate some checks) but it'll be significantly more complicated & awkward to maintain, risks diverging behaviour, and this is explicitly the slow path anyway.

Happy to explore that if people would prefer, but personally I'd lean towards keeping it simpler, and recommending that people don't mix setHeader/writeHead in performance-sensitive environments. I think that's a reasonable recommendation that most code written for such scenarios will likely be doing anyway.

issue.title: events: static properties are configurable & writable

labels.name: good first issue
labels.description: Issues that are suitable for first-time contributors.

labels.name: eventtarget
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the EventTarget implementation.

issue.body:
### Version

v22

### Platform

n/a

### Subsystem

events

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

```js
Event.NONE = 'lol'
Event.CAPTURING_PHASE = 'lol'
Event.AT_TARGET = 'lol'
Event.BUBBLING_PHASE = 'lol'

Event.NONE // 'lol', should be 0
Event.CAPTURING_PHASE // 'lol', should be 1
Event.AT_TARGET // 'lol', should be 2
Event.BUBBLING_PHASE // 'lol', should be 3
```

### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

n/a

### What is the expected behavior? Why is that the expected behavior?

The [idl](https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#interface-event) definition for Event makes these properties constants. That means that they shouldn't be configurable or writable.

```js
const props = ['NONE', 'CAPTURING_PHASE', 'AT_TARGET', 'BUBBLING_PHASE']

for (const prop of props) {
  const desc = Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor(Event, prop)

  assert.strictEqual(desc.writable, false)
  assert.strictEqual(desc.configurable, false)
  assert.strictEqual(desc.enumerable, true)
}
```

### What do you see instead?

shown above

### Additional information

take a look at how it's being done for prototypical methods/properties, but do that for Event with the properties mentioned above.
https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/6431c657d9dd8b75ea71956461870be7ba9d89b8/lib/internal/event_target.js#L324

comment.body: Not sure if someone is already working on it actively, but I'm taking a look :)

WIP

Locally tested and I found that it is much faster without a prototype when creating, and has some impact on runtime, so this is me playing with it

I'm running all events benchmarks on purpose so will see the effect `{ __proto__: null }` hint v8 to use the dictionary mode [`src/runtime/runtime-literals.cc` in V8](https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:v8/src/runtime/runtime-literals.cc;l=384-391;bpv=1;bpt=1?q=createobjectliteral) (founded by `@benjamingr`)

pull_request.body:
WIP

Locally tested and I found that it is much faster without a prototype when creating, and has some impact on runtime, so this is me playing with it

I'm running all events benchmarks on purpose so will see the effect `{ __proto__: null }` hint v8 to use the dictionary mode [`src/runtime/runtime-literals.cc` in V8](https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:v8/src/runtime/runtime-literals.cc;l=384-391;bpv=1;bpt=1?q=createobjectliteral) (founded by `@benjamingr`)

comment.body:
So it seems the cause is that:

1. We parse addons.md to generate addon tests
2. The parser used to parse addons.md depends on i18n to work (via remark-gfm?)

Not sure how this can be addressed easily. I think we do still want to test the addons in addons.md in without-intl builds. Perhaps we can just some dumb marker in addons.md and write a custom parser instead of using remark.

comment.body:
> Maybe either something was missed there or we've subsequently changed something in how the docs are generated that means they're no longer being skipped?

Do we have other Node.js installations available in the system? https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/41091 checks the availability of intl using whatever Node.js binary available in the system (`out/Release/node` just takes precedence). If somehow there's a node executable with Intl on the path, that check could be invalid
